Week 37: Rosh Hashanah

17 Sep 2023
  • Cooler temperatures! After the hottest week I‚Äôve experienced in months, things were back to comfortable Summer weather. By the time I‚Äôm writing this the sky is gray and it‚Äôs raining, but this week‚Äôs weather was cheerful and moderate.
  • On Tuesday and Wednesday I gave two big UX workshops at week to help coworkers understand how they can use UX in their daily work. I‚Äôve been giving workshops for well over a decade, always trusting my instinct to figure out what a particular group or context required. At work, though, we have two wonderful scrum masters who are well-versed in the art of facilitation. I learned a lot from their feedback, and saw a hugh jump between the quality of the first day and of the second day.
  • I caught up with a special friend on Wednesday, a young woman I met because we were treated for the same health condition. Her life as a Psych major couldn‚Äôt be more different from mine, and yet the red threads our lives resemble one another. I‚Äôm fortunate to call her my friend.
  • I had missed a few weeks in my RSS reader, but I was pleased to see Manuel Moreale‚Äôs People & Blogs is off to a good start. To hell with Anja calling me a geek for being into the IndieWeb, I love visiting other people‚Äôs websites. I suspect I love reading what they have to say about those websites even more.
  • Last week, I had met an amazing couple of lesbians who invited me over for a casual dinner party on Friday. After a particularly challenging week, it was comforting to hear their experiences as people of color in the world today. I‚Äôm already looking forward to inviting them to our place.
  • On Saturday, Anja and I kicked off the weekend with a spontaneous redesign of our living room. We finally got rid of my desk, which was a Covid-era purchase used for our home office. What remains now is Anja‚Äôs bigger desk, which functions as a dining room table that she hates more than I do. The removal of our home office allowed us to place our sofa there, which has giving the living room a significant amount of extra space. The dining room table continues to double as an office whenever we put our ultrawide monitor there. I like modular living , and I‚Äôm feeling less and less awkward about the way we‚Äôre going about it in our house.
  • At the end of our cleaning sprint Anja mentioned it was a beautiful day for this accomplishment, since it was Rosh Hashanah. New living room, new beginnings.
  • After visiting Anja‚Äôs mom in the afternoon, we biked to Kriterion to Watch Oppenheimer (2023) .
  • Much like the last few days, I‚Äôm not in the best of states. There‚Äôs an old sadness that keeps saying hello, and I‚Äôm slowly beginning to think it might be time to get some help with it.
  • I‚Äôm nearing the end of my journal, and I‚Äôm surprised by how unnervous I am by the few pages I have left. In this past, like the rest of the world, as it appears, I had trouble finishing a journal in a relaxed manner. Looking at the first entry, I see I have 29 days left until it‚Äôll have been one year exactly. Hello nerves.

As per my privacy policy, I won't know you've been here unless you tell me. Let me know what you think about this either via email, Mastodon or webmention. I would love to hear from you!

Zinzy Waleson Geene is an Afropean, queer researcher and designer from Amsterdam (NL).
